In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here's how you can write the Julia function:

```julia
function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3)
    dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end

# Use it as follows
using Dates
dt = now()
bump_by_three = timezone_bumper(dt)  # This will add 3 hours to the current time
bump_by_five = timezone_bumper(dt,5)  # You can bump by any number of hours
```

This function takes a `DateTime` object and an optional `Int` parameter (defaulting to `3`) as arguments. It then returns the original date-time object increased by that many hours. Note that this does not change the timezone, it merely shifts the time forward or backward.

If you attempt to use it with a `Date` object instead of a `DateTime`, it will throw an error:

```julia
bump_by_three = timezone_bumper(today())  # This will throw an error
```
